title: Structure Definition
intro: Visually expressing the structure of your company, along with the groups & teams within it, gives you an overview serving as a starting point for building SWI workflows and distributing Standard Work templates to the places in your business where they are needed.

blocks.content: FieldLogs Enterprise provides a simple tree based enterprise structure that an administrator of an Enterprise account can build and maintain. FieldLogs Enterprise uses Groups to structure a hierarchy of members to give maximum flexibility in emulating a variety of organizational structures and to reinforce a Data Scope (detailed below).

Members (namely administrators) with the correct security permissions can create entities in the Hierarchy by clicking the 'Add' button or hovering over an element and clicking the smaller add button that appears in the cell.

When adding entities to your Hierarchy it is important to understand their scope and it's importance in data separation for the various groups of your Enterprise structure. As an example, members in a Group at the root level will not have access to Templates at the root level itself, only to Templates inside the Group they have been assigned. They will, however, have access to any sub-Groups created inside it. This allows an administrator to create a structure where the data between various departments is separate.

blocks.caption:
In this structure, the data (Templates & Jobs) of Group 'OGBU1' will only be accessible by members directly associated with this Group; in this case there are two:OGManager1 & OGUser2.

The data associated with the sub-group 'OGSubBU1' is accessible by its members OGManager2, OGUser2 & OGUser4 and is also accessible by the main groups members (OGBU1) since 'OGSubBU1' is a child entity of its parent, 'OGBU1'.

Using this logic it is easy to see therefore, that all data associated with both Group entities mentioned above is accessible by members associated with the root of the Enterprise 'OilGasNewCorp' (OGUser1 & OGUser9) since the group OGBU1 is a child entity of the root.

This is an example of the data scope used by FieldLogs that allows maximum flexibility to all manner of organization structures.

blocks.content: Now is an appropriate time to introduce a few more concepts used by FieldLogs, particularly in relation to the concept of Template Lifecycles. For more detail about Lifecycles themselves, refer to Template Lifecycle Definition. Here we will cover their significance in relation to the Hierarchy structure & data scope.

points.text: Groups are general entities that group members and all the other structural elements to build the tree structure. Groups, for example, can be nested inside other Groups. These can come to mean whatever is required for your organisations structure.

Template DBs are repositories of Templates with the same level of access as other entities inside its parent group. They store approved Templates that are of use to a particular group for job execution.
Lifecycles are specific authoring workflows for Templates that produce 'Published' Templates and store them in Template DBs for access by the Enterprise.

blocks.caption: This is the root of the Enterprise from which all Enterprise structures can start to be defined. Members added at this level will be able to view & edit (depending on their security role) Templates of the entire Enterprise.

An example of a Template DB within the specific group, 'OGBU2', which also contains a Lifecycle 'OGBU2 Template Lifecycle'. Templates authored with this Lifecycle will be stored in the DB 'OGBU2PublicRepository. Please see Template Lifecycle Definition for information about the difference between Public and Private repositories.

This designates a Lifecycle that can be used by group members to collaboratively 'approve' Templates for use in the Enterprise. Templates approved using this Lifecycle will be stored in the 'OGBU2PublicRepository' repository.
Once turned on, it is possible to see where members are within the hierarchy. It is possible to see a simple count at all times on the right side of any Group in the Hierarchy window.
